thread.title: High school football: Wasatch defense shines in win over Maple Mountain
thread.title_full: High school football: Wasatch defense shines in win over Maple Mountain | Deseret News

author: Kenny Bristow
title: High school football: Wasatch defense shines in win over Maple Mountain
text:
The Wasatch Wasps took sole possession of second place in Region 8 following their 22-7 victory over visiting Maple Mountain on Friday night.
Scoreboard » Maple Mountain Wasatch 7 22 See more stats » More Coverage High school football: T-Birds turn back Chargers, all but clinch Region 7 crown High school football roundup for Friday, Oct. 9 Herriman survives late comeback by American Fork to capture a 23-15 win “ We try and take away any opponents biggest weapons so we just played against the deep ball early and went with a 3-man front to get more skill guys on the field. It played out well for us tonight. This is another huge win and a great performance, especially by our defense.”
Wasatch head coach Steve Coburn
HEBER CITY — When the Maple Mountain Golden Eagles traveled to Wasatch on Friday night for their crucial contest for second place in Region 8, they knew their passing game would have to be in top form against the tough Wasp defense.
That turned out to be a taller order than expected as Wasatch played its stingiest game of the season, shutting down the high-powered Golden Eagle offense and winning 22-7.
The seven points were the fewest the Wasps, who nearly pitched a shutout, have allowed this season.
“This was a very good offensive football team and Jaren Hall is a very good quarterback,” said Wasatch coach Steve Coburn . “We try and take away any opponent’s biggest weapons so we just played against the deep ball early and went with a three-man front to get more skill guys on the field. It played out well for us tonight. This is another huge win and a great performance, especially by our defense.”
Wasatch undoubtedly benefitted from the fact that Hall was forced out of the game with a left ankle injury in the second quarter and did not return.
That allowed the home team to turn up the pressure and give Maple Mountain very little to work with, forcing the Golden Eagles to punt seven times.
Wasatch, celebrating homecoming before a packed house at Wright-Tree Stadium, was dominant in all phases of the game except one — scoring touchdowns.
Not until the final quarter with just over three minutes remaining did the Wasps finally reach pay dirt.
Tailback Kade Trowbridge scored on a 3-yard burst on first-and-goal following a mishandled snap by the Maple Mountain punter to ice the game for the home team.
That touchdown and the extra point kick gave Wasatch its 22 points, but the 15 scored before that all came off the foot of the Wasps All-American kicker Skyler Southam .
Southam connected on field goals from 44, 34, 53, 19 and 38 yards. His five makes tied a Utah state record for most field goals in a game and his third make on the night tied the record for most made in a single season. The kicker now has 19 so far.
“Obviously we’re a little frustrated with our offense tonight,” said Coburn. “We had chances to get in the end zone, but we’ve built our offense for this. Skyler is a tremendous weapon and if we can get within his range, we’re taking the points.”
The Wasps moved the ball with ease in between the 20's, but failed to get the touchdowns to put the game away early.
Wasatch scored on its first possession with Southam’s 27-yard field goal and never looked back. Despite adding two more in the second quarter, the Wasp lead never felt comfortable.
Leading 9-0 with 4:20 remaining in the third period, the Wasps seemed to have the play to break it open. Maple Mountain's backup quarterback was intercepted by defensive back Nick Piscitelli and returned for a 25-yard touchdown.
A block-in-the-back penalty called the play back giving Wasatch first down at the visitors' 33-yard line. The Wasps failed to reach the end zone despite the turnover in good field position.
A second Wasatch interception, this time by Carson Mahoney early in the fourth quarter, set the Wasps up with first-and-10 at the Maple Mountain 15. Wasatch could not find the end zone, however, and called on Southam for his fourth field goal.
The kicker added his record-tying fifth field goal just over three minutes later.
After Wasatch finally managed to score that elusive touchdown making it 22-0 after the PAT, the Wasps began to celebrate knowing they had just taken hold of their third region victory.
Maple Mountain backup quarterback Austin Edwards guided the visitors down the field for an 18-yard touchdown pass to receiver Dawson Beutler to avoid the shutout.
The win puts Wasatch, now 3-1, in sole possession of second place in Region 8 and in good position for the postseason. Maple Mountain fell to 2-2 and into a third-place tie with Salem Hills and Spanish Fork.
Kenny Bristow is the sports editor and staff sports writer for the Wasatch Wave and contributes to the Deseret News high school coverage for the Wasatch region. Email: kennywbristow@gmail.com and follow him on Twitter, Google+ and Facebook.
